column4: My external hard drive has magically changed from writeable to read-only without me changing fstab. Help!
My external hard drive has magically changed from writeable to read-only without me changing fstab. Help!
ntfs?
vfat
were any other users logged on when it was connected?
i'm the sole user
what does "ls -ld /media/mountpoint" say? (with the proper mountpoint of course)
all it does is tell me there's differences between boot sector and it's backup.
I think anirudh0's suggestion is a good idea btw. unmount and run fsck.vfat or dosfsck on the partition. This may be caused by filesystem error
then:  File system has 2441533 clusters but only space for 2441470 FAT entries
oh, that kindof make it sound like there's too many files on it ...
shouldn't be
how in the world can there be "too many files on a hard drive?"
ok, once again, how can there be too many files on a hard drive?
ok, for the third time, how can there be "too many files" on a hard drive?
there's a limit to how many files a filesystem can addresss
and why would that lock me out of MOVING something off a hard drive?
and why doesn't this lock me out of the hard drive on a windows box?
I don't know if that is the case. I don't have that much knowledge about fat filesystems, I'm making guesses
according to google, there's a maximum number of files in each directory, I can't find anything of a total ... but anyway, having windows to a scandisk or chkdisk on the drive might fix things
